docs.lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg released two budget proposals yesterday, a $44.5 billion best-case plan that he described as ''painful'' and a backup plan of $1 billion less that he said would be ''devastating.'' Even the best-case situation includes many of the toughest cuts Mr. Bloomberg has sought in his 15 months as mayor. It calls for laying off 4,500 city workers, including teachers' aides, the most layoffs in the city since 1991. A dozen children's clinics would be closed, a vaunted police antidrug operation would cease, rush-hour trips by the Staten Island ferry would be reduced, zoos in Brooklyn and Queens would close, and the twinkly lights atop the city's East River bridges -- which have been dark for several weeks now -- would be doused permanently to save money.

headline.main: Bloomberg Offers Two Budgets, One Bleak and the Other Bleaker

docs.abstract: Mayor Michael R Bloomberg releases two budget proposals: 'painful' $44.5 billion best-case plan and 'devastating' plan of $1 billion less that he says he would be forced to enact if state does not give city more aid and approve his request for commuter tax and if city's unions resist concessions; even best-case plan would require layoff of 4,500 city workers, closing of dozen children's clinics, halting of Operation Condor anti-drug program, reduction in Staten Island ferry rush-hour trips, closing of zoos in Brooklyn and Queens and darkening of lights on East River bridges; 'doomsday' plan would mean 10,000 more layoffs, dirtier streets, closing of up to 40 firehouses, elimination of after-school programs, closing of all city pools, elimination of subway and bus discounts for the elderly and shrinking of Police Department to lowest level in years; budget presentation sets off new round of sparring with labor unions and gets mixed reaction from City Council; photo; graphs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Medical and life insurance companies are banned from discriminating against victims of domestic abuse under a bill signed yesterday by Gov. James E. McGreevey. Supporters say some insurers have denied coverage and in some cases limited benefits to victims. If state regulators find violations, fines can range up to $5,000. The new law also gives regulators the power to file state and federal lawsuits against insurance companies to collect damages. ''Insurers who discriminate against victims of domestic violence contribute to the misguided and unfortunate tradition of blaming the victim,'' said the bill's sponsor, Senator Barbara Buono, Democrat of Middlesex.

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki defiantly shifted the burden of solving New York's budget crisis onto the State Legislature today, saying its two top leaders had offered no concrete alternatives to the plan he submitted 75 days ago. Mr. Pataki, a Republican who has all but drawn a line in the sand against tax increases to help the state and city out of their financial problems, said that besides demanding increased spending on health care and education, the two legislative leaders had agreed on little else: what cuts to restore or how to pay for them.

docs.lead_paragraph: With Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg ordering layoffs for 5,401 city workers, New York City's municipal unions are facing their biggest squeeze in three decades and are in unusual disarray about how to deal with it. The unions representing more than 300,000 municipal workers are feuding over whether to offer more than minimal contract concessions to the city. Some labor leaders say they would much prefer layoffs to compromises that would hit union members' wallets.

headline.main: Labor Lacks United Front In the Battle To Save Jobs
